15 hours ago, Cavscout74 said:

They've previously said (and no I don't remember where, but it was posted on here somewhere) the main game mode would be more like science than career mode, so unless that was incorrect, it implies no funds or contracts, and therefore no reason to launch tourists.  It's actually the first thing I saw that shifted my opinion of KSP2 from "buy it the day it releases" to "I'll wait & see"

It implies that their not copying the exact gameplay as seen in KSP, and that's it, everything else is just speculation on our part. That's a good thing, career and science are not exactly brilliant pieces of game design, they're barely more than placeholders for some feature that never got implemented (just like an actual texture for the Oscar-B).

In light of what we've seen of KSP2 contracts and funds are in a weird position, in KSP1 they're there as a "make-believe tool" to help you pretend your bases, stations and satellites have an actual use and are not completely inert and useless crafts. In KSP2 you won't need that, stations, bases will not be empty shells but research bases, mining outposts, refineries, factories, launch centers, colonies, orbital shipyards and cities.

Even in the most barebone implementation possible they'll have a functionality, they'll need you to build them, transfer resources and rotate or move crews, that completely kills the reason funds, but especially contracts, were put into KSP1.

That means that contracts, funds or tourism will not be in KSP2 or will be useless? No, but it means that their main reason to exist in KSP1 has been solved in another, better, way and if they're there in KSP2 they'll be used for other reasons as tutorials, additional gameplay mechanics or alternative gameplay loops and not to cover the utter uselessness of building and launching anything bigger than a scientist on a chair with a bunch of science tools and the best probe core you've unlocked.

Edited March 13, 2021 by Master39
